qas.question: What is the main trial court called?

answers.text: The Philadelphia County Court of Common Pleas (First Judicial District)

qas.question: What type of cases are heard here?

answers.text: felony-level criminal cases and civil suits above the minimum jurisdictional limit of $7000

qas.question: Who was the last Republican DA?

context: <a0_0>The Philadelphia County Court of Common Pleas (First Judicial District)<a0_0/> is the trial court of general jurisdiction for Philadelphia, hearing <a1_0>felony-level criminal cases and civil suits above the minimum jurisdictional limit of $7000<a1_0/> (excepting small claims cases valued between $7000 and $12000 and landlord-tenant issues heard in the Municipal Court) under its original jurisdiction; it also has appellate jurisdiction over rulings from the Municipal and Traffic Courts and over decisions of certain Pennsylvania state agencies (e.g. the Pennsylvania Liquor Control Board). It has 90 legally trained judges <a2_0>elected by the voters<a2_0/>. It is funded and operated largely by city resources and employees. The current District Attorney is Seth Williams, a Democrat. The last Republican to hold the office is <a3_0>Ron Castille<a3_0/>, who left in 1991 and is currently the Chief Justice of the Pennsylvania Supreme Court.
